Fossil fuel combustion results in significant NOx emissions, which are harmful to the environment and human health. The reasonable and effective treatment of NOx pollution is an urgent requirement. The electrocatalytic reduction of nitric oxide (NORR) to ammonia is an emerging method that can convert the NO pollutant into an important industrial product under ambient conditions, exhibiting great advantages over the severe reaction conditions of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) and Haber-Bosch processes of NH3 synthesis, therefore, attracting the great interest of researchers. In the last few years, lots of materials for NORR have been developed based on theoretical, computational, or experimental studies. However, further breakthroughs in the catalytic activity, selectivity, and Faraday efficiency of NORR electrocatalysts are required to address the limitations in practical applications. To help future research on NORR in both theoretical and experimental directions, we summarized the recent progress in the development of NORR electrocatalysts, classifying them into metals and alloys, metal compounds, and non-metal materials according to their nature. The mechanisms or reaction pathways of NORR are also discussed. Furthermore, the experimental parameters and devices for NORR are introduced to help with experimental studies in the future. The research directions and perspectives on the further development of NORR electrocatalysts are illustrated. Graphical abstract This review summarizes the recent advancements in NORR on parameters, experimental, mechanism, and catalysts, illustrating the types of catalysts, and the strategies for improving activity. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrocatalytic reduction Nitric oxide Ammonia Mechanism Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The nitric oxides (NOx) released from the burning of fossil fuels are responsible for significant environmental issues, such as aerosol nitrates, acid rain, photochemical smog, haze, and ozone layer depletion[1–4], as well as the serious respiratory and neurological health effects [5–7]. Consequently, various technologies for NO elimination have been developed, including selective catalytic reduction (SCR) [8–10], NOx storage reduction (NSR) [11–13], three-way catalysis [14–16], continuous regenerative trap (CRT) [17–20], photocatalysis [21–23], and electrocatalysis [24–26]. We compared the typical process of SCR [27], Haber-Bosch process for ammonia synthesis [28], and the photocatalysis process [29] in Fig. 1 , and found that the SCR and Haber-Bosch process are costly, complicated, and require harsh conditions such as high temperature and pressure, as well as reducing agent NH3 [30–32]. The photocatalysis process require moderate conditions, but also shows complicated path ways to remove the NOx, and normally with a very low conversion rate. The electrocatalytic reduction of NO (NORR) to ammonia (NH3) at mild conditions of room temperature, atmospheric pressure, and low voltage could be an ideal replacement, but the NORR hasn't been widely investigated. We have searched the publication record on Web of Science using “electrocatalytic reduction of nitric oxide to ammonia” as the topic and excluded “nitrate” and found the investigations on NORR are getting hot in the recent two years, as shown in Fig. 2 A. Ammonia is one of the most crucial fundamental chemicals used in the agricultural, industrial, pharmaceutical, and military industries [34]. It is also a promising hydrogen carrier due to the high hydrogen content (17.65%), energy density (4.3 kW∙h∙kg−1), and mild storage conditions (25 °C, 9∼10 bar) [35,36]. For a century, the Haber-Bosch process is used for NH3 synthesis, with NH3 yield of only 15∼20%, which is an energy-consuming process and requires harsh conditions, significant investment, and running costs [37]. Recently, the electrocatalytic synthesis of NH3 from N2 and H2O (NRR) shows the potential to address the drawbacks of Haber-Bosch process, which only requires simple equipment's and moderate reaction conditions [38]. However, the NH3 yields of NRR are far away from the targeting 9.3 × 10−7 mol∙cm−1∙s − 1 of the US Department of Energy (DOE) for industrial-level applications [39], which could be attributed to the stable NN bond (941 kJ∙mol−1), and thermodynamically prohibited first step protonation of N2 in NRR (∆H 0 = 37.6 kJ∙mol−1) [40]. The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) also significantly affects the Faraday efficiency and NH3 yield of NRR [41]. The electrocatalytic reduction of NO (NORR) is more active for efficient NH3 production, which is kinetically and thermodynamically much easier than NRR due to the lower bond energy (204 kJ∙mol−1) than NN bond (941 kJ∙mol−1), higher water solubility (1.94 mmol∙L − 1∙atm−1), and higher reduction potential (E 0 = 0.092 V) [42]. Long et al. proved that the reduction of NO to NH3 is more feasible than NRR and HER [43]. The NO is a crucial intermediate in several significant industrial and environmental processes, including the hydrogenation of nitric oxide in liquid phases or the conversion of nitrate to hydroxylamine. Therefore, the study of NORR is crucial for understanding the fundamentals of nitric oxide, NO3 −/NO2 − electrocatalytic reduction, and creating effective technologies with high selectivity and activity [42,43]. The NORR strategy not only enables the synthesis of valuable NH3 for industry and agriculture but also addresses the issue of exhausted NOx, resulting in the full utilization of N sources and energy, as illustrated in Fig. 2B. Currently, the investigation on NORR is still in its infancy. Most of the studies are focusing on theoretical calculations, which can reveal the catalytic mechanisms, and guide the selection and design of efficient materials for NORR. The theoretical outcomes could be proved by experimental studies [44,45]. Therefore, a comprehensive review is necessary for the researchers working on NORR and related areas. In this review, we summarized the recent advances in NORR, illustrating the potential strategies to promote NORR activity through (1) electrochemical devices, (2) additives in electrolytes, and (3) the development of efficient electrocatalysts. We anticipate that this review will be beneficial for ongoing research on NORR and the related electrocatalytic reduction of nitrate and nitrite. 2 Experimental parameters for NORR 2.1 The calculation of NH3 yield The precise measurement of NH3 production is critical for NORR. In prior studies, the following equation was used to determine NH3 yield [46]: (1) NH 3 yield = C N H 3 × V t × m c a t . where V is the volume of electrolyte solution, C NH3 is the concentration of NH3, t is the electrolysis reaction time, and m cat. is the mass of the catalyst. Various sources use different units of NH3 yield, such as pmol·s − 1·cm−2 [47], μmol·cm−2·h − 1, mol·cm−2·s − 1[48], μg·h − 1·cm−2 [49], μg·h − 1·mg−1 [46], μmol·h − 1·mg−1 [33], and so on, to express the mass or molar quantities of NH3 produced in a unit time and unit catalyst mass or area. The uniformity of the unit of NH3 yield will be required in the future for researchers to promote speedy communication and comparison among peers. 2.2 The calculation of faradaic efficiency Faradaic Efficiency (FE) is employed to demonstrate the proportion of input energy used for the NH3 production, which is influenced by the side reactions creating by-products such as H2, N2O, N2H4, N2O2, and NH2OH, to assess the selectivity of NH3 in the NORR process. The following equation is used to determine the FE [46]: (2) FE = C N H 3 × V × n × F Q × 100 % where n is the total number of electrons transferred for production, F is the Faraday constant (96,485 C·mol−1), V is the volume of the electrolyte solution, CNH3 is the measured NH3 concentration, and Q is the area calculated by integrating the corresponding i-t curve to show the total number of electrons transferred. 2.3 The stability of catalyst For the practical application of catalysts, stability is a crucial criterion. The catalysts employed in the industry should maintain their shape, structure, and catalytic activity over an extended period or repeatedly. The NORR catalysts still have significant shortcomings, such as the atomic aggregation of single-atom catalysts [50] and the corrosion of metal catalysts [51]. In the current studies, the stability of catalysts can be estimated by the density functional theory (DFT) calculation [50], but the experimental investigation is still necessary to confirm the stability by repeated measurement more than 10 times or lasting for more than 10 h to achieve a stable NH3 yield and FE [52–54]. 2.4 Methods for NH3 detection Accurate measurement of generated ammonia in the NORR is necessary for both the calculation of NH3 yield and Faraday efficiency. Due to the great solubility of ammonia in water (482 g·L − 1 at 24 °C), quantitative measurements of ammonia are typically carried out in aqueous solutions [55]. Some numerous analytical techniques and tools have been used to measure ammonia concentrations, including Nessler's reagent method, indophenol blue method, salicylate method, ion chromatography, ammonia gas-sensing electrode, ammonium ion-selective electrode, fluorometric method, conductivity method, titrimetric method, and enzymatic method [34,56]. The ion chromatography shows the advantages of high sensitivity, good reproducibility, simultaneous determination of multiple ions in a short time, and the possibility of using different detectors (conductometric, fluorimetric, UV–vis, etc.), but it requires expensive and complex instruments. The 1H NMR is effective in isotope investigations, which can be used to confirm the origin of ammonia N in NORR utilizing 15N-labeled NO as the feed gas. While the Watt and Chrisp method is commonly used to identify the byproduct hydrazine (N2H4) [57]. The online gas chromatograph (GC) with an HP-PLOT 5A column and a pulsed discharge detector is shown in Fig. 3 A as part of a systematic analytical system for NORR. It is used to determine the type and yield of the gaseous products (N2O, N2, and H2) produced in the cathodic chamber [43,58]. To confirm the origin of ammonia and other nitrogen-containing contaminants, they also used 15NO isotope labeling. The results are more exact thanks to the systematic analytical system, but the expense and operational difficulty of the experiment rise with the precision instruments. The indophenol blue method is frequently used as a standard reference method for measuring low concentrations of ammonia nitrogen (0–0.6 mg NH3 N L − 1) since it is based on the Berthelot reaction, in which ammonia interacts with phenol and hypochlorite in alkaline solution [56]. Because of the small interference from organic nitrogen molecules, nitrite, nitrate, and different electrolytes, the indophenol blue method is only selective for ammonia species. Peng et al. used a spectrophotometer to measure the absorbance at a wavelength of 655 nm to quantify the amounts of ammonia, as shown in Fig. 3B [48]. Standard ammonia chloride solutions were used to calibrate the concentration-absorbance curves. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and Nessler's reagent method are also frequently employed to detect ammonia [59]. Although the spectrophotometric methods described above have been widely used in electrochemical nitrogen fixation (NRR), the amount of ammonia produced by NRR is typically quite small and is easily influenced by contaminations, other nitrogen-containing compounds in the nitrogen gas stream, or residual N-containing surfactants on the catalysts [60–62]. The NH3 yield of NORR, on the other hand, is many orders of magnitude higher than that of NRR, since the reduction of gaseous oxidized forms of nitrogen to NH3 is easier and occurs at substantially lower negative potentials than that of nitrate and nitrite anions [46,63]. Because of the large difference in NH3 output, the effect of airborne N2 on NORR is sometimes minimal. 3 Strategies to improve NORR performances 3.1 The effect of electrochemical devices The reaction devices have a significant influence on the NH3 yield and Faraday efficiency. Fig. 4 A shows a single-chamber electrolytic cell that has been widely used in many research areas (including NORR) due to its low cost, easy operation, and good stability [46,64–67]. However, oxidation reactions will occur alongside reduction reactions in the three-electrode single-reaction system, leading to biased results in the detection of reduction products [68]. To overcome this restriction, an H-type electrochemical cell (shown in Fig. 4B) is used for NORR, which can theoretically prevent the movement of NH4 + production across the proton membrane, therefore, inhibit its electrochemical oxidation to N2 or nitrogen oxides (N2O and NO) [35,43,58,69,70]. There is still a tiny amount of ammonia that can pass through the Nafion membranes due to thermal movement and is electro-oxidized in the anode cell [71]. Furthermore, the lifetime of the Nafion membrane will be influenced by the interaction between the sulphonic acid group and ammonia, leading to inaccurate experimental results. Hence, the H-type electrochemical cell should be further improved when being applied in NORR and NRR. The flow cell shows advantages over conventional H-type cells, which can improve the mass transfer and control the movement of electrolytes in and out of the cathode and anode chambers. The flow cell can immediately remove the generated NH3 from the cell to maintain the low NH3 concentration in the cathode chamber, therefore, facilitating the timely dissolution of NH3 in the NORR process [33]. Moreover, gas diffusion electrodes (GDEs)-based flow cells can greatly enhance the performance of gas-involved electrocatalytic reactions, such as CO2RR, CORR, and NRR [72]. Fig. 4C shows a GDEs-based three-channel flow cell that has been applied in the NORR using B, N co-doped carbon nanotubes with Nb single metal atom as working electrode, achieving an extremely high NH3 yield of 8.2 × 10−8 mol∙cm−2∙s − 1 [48]. Cheon et al. also reported the electrocatalytic reduction of dilute NO by carbon black catalyst on a gas diffusion electrode, achieving a 96% Faradaic efficiency with 1% NO, and an NH3 yield of 1239 μmol∙cm−2∙h − 1 with 10% NO [73]. Inspired by the studies on NH3 generation from N2 using metal-N2 batteries, Sun's group developed a series of Metal-NO battery cells for the NORR process [49,75,76], which combines the processes of energy generation, NH3 production, and NO treatment. As illustrated in Fig. 4D (left), a Zn-NO reaction for the conversion of NO into ammonia is performed in the H-shaped electrolytic reactor with a Zn plate as anode and Ni2P/CP as the cathode in 0.1 M HCl electrolyte, achieving a FE of 76.9% and NH3 yield of 33.47 μmol∙h − 1∙cm−2 at −0.2 V [75]. When the NORR is performed in the Zn-NO battery in Fig. 4D (right), it will result in an NH3 yield of 62.05 μg∙h − 1∙mg−1 and deliver a discharge power density of 1.53 mW∙cm−2. This Zn-NO battery offers a greater output voltage of 2.06 V than many metal-air batteries and a higher NH3 yield than most metal-N2 battery systems. In addition to the Ni2P/CP, other materials can also be applied as the working electrode to assemble Zn-NO batteries to achieve the simultaneous discharge and NH3 production, such as NiO/TM [49], Bi NDs/CP [76], MoS2/GF [77], and NiFe-LDH [78]. 3.2 The effect of additives on electrolytes Electrolytes, in addition to electrocatalytic devices, are crucial as a medium for proton transfer and electron transport during electrocatalytic reactions. The Li-mediated electrolytes, ionic liquid electrolytes, organic solvent electrolytes, aqueous electrolytes, and solid electrolytes have all been employed in the NRR process, which could also be applied in the NORR process. The most often employed electrolytes are aqueous (e.g., K2SO4, Li2SO4, Na2SO4, HCl, and PBS), in which the NO will be dissolved and reduced on the surface of the electrode. However, the solubility of NO in water is low (∼1.94 mM at 25 °C), which greatly restrict the production rate of NH3 from the direct NORR in aqueous electrolyte. To increase the amount of NO in the electrolyte for NORR reaction, some metal complexes additives, such as Fe2+-EDTA (EFeMC) [49,58], iron (II) sodium benzoate (FeIISB) [77], and ferrous citrate (FeIICit) [79], can be added into electrolytes, which can rapidly capture NO molecules and improve the solubility of NO, therefore, boosting the NH3 yield of NORR. Fig. 5 A illustrates the device and the reaction process of NO on the cathode of Pt, Ag, or GC. The EFeMC can trap NO to improve its solubility in the electrolyte solution, resulting in favorable reaction-free energy and facilitating electron transfer, leading to a FE of 100%. The DFT calculation results show that the HNO pathway is more favorable than the NOH pathway in the sequential hydrogenation of NO by proton-coupled electron transfer, with the synthesis of *HNO intermediate being identified as the rate-limiting step. To avoid the effect of EDTA on the detection of NH3, Xiong et al. [79] applied FeIICit as the electrolyte to capture NO, forming NH3 through a protonating pathway, as illustrated in Fig. 5B, achieving the liquid-solid reaction of FeII(NO)Cit to NH3, instead of the gas-solid reaction of NO to NH3 on the cathode, which shows an average NH3 yield of 14.6 μmol∙h − 1∙cm−2 and FE of 65.2% at −0.1 V vs RHE. Although the addition of metal complexes can enhance the production of ammonia, it raises the cost of NORR and is not suitable for direct use as green ammonia fertilizer in agriculture. 3.3 The development of efficient norr electrocatalysts Although the above strategies have a significant influence on NORR, the catalyst is the most important parameter that determines NORR performance. The NORR catalysts should have high NH3 yield and Faraday efficiency, good selectivity, and long-term stability, as well as mechanical and thermodynamical stability. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation is a powerful tool in the design and selection of effective NORR catalysts [80]. At the early stage, most of the studies on NORR are based on theoretical calculation, investigating the adsorption performance of NO molecules on the surface of catalysts, the density of states, reaction pathway, rate-limiting step, and so on, therefore, indicating the potential of the selected materials for NORR. Based on these published studies, we summarized the elementals that have been investigated in NORR, which are in the forms of metals, alloys, single atoms, metal oxides, sulfides, phosphides, MOFs, MXenes, MBenes, and various non-metal materials as catalysts or substrates, as marked in the periodic table of elements of Fig. 6 . It can be observed that most of the studies are focusing on the noble metals and alloys, transition metal compounds, and C-, N-, P- and B- based non-metal materials. 3.3.1 Noble metals and alloys Although Au and Ag are efficient for electrocatalytic water splitting, nitrogen reduction, and CO2 reduction, their performances in NORR lack investigations. As shown in Fig. 7 A, the DFT calculation results indicate that the binding of *NO on Au and Ag is unfavorable [81], which is theoretically not suitable for NORR. While the metals below the horizontal line bind well with the *NO, which can be selected for NORR. But the metals like Pt and Pd can bind with both *NO and *H, resulting in competitive HER at a potential below 0 V vs. RHE. Although Au is theoretically regarded as having no NORR activity, there is still an experimental report that confirms the activity of Au in the reduction of N2, N2O, NO, NO2, NO2 −, and NO3 − to ammonia, achieving an NH3 yield of (8.1 ± 0.9) × 102 pmol∙s − 1∙cm−2 at −0.3 V from NO [47]. However, the NH3 yield is very low as the reduction of NO only occurs at the potential where Au has a low *H coverage, while H2 is the main product at a more negative potential. The NO reduction on Pt is much easier than Au and Ag. NO can be electrochemically reduced into nitrogen (N2), nitrous oxide (N2O), as well as ammonia (NH3/NH4 +), on the surface of single-crystal Pt electrodes [44]. The products are determined by the applied potential and the form of NO in the reaction system. When NO is in the adsorbed state on the catalyst surface, it will be reduced into NH3. While the products of NO in the solution are determined by the potentials, which could be N2O at potentials of 0.4 V and 0.8 V vs RHE, and NH3 at a potential of less than 0.4 V. The NORR catalytic activity is also influenced by the morphology and structure of the catalyst. Cheng et al. [82] studied the NORR performance of Pt-NP, Pt-Thorn, and Pt-THH using cyclic voltammetry (CV), as shown in Fig. 7B. The NO reduction current densities of Pt-THH and Pt-Thorn are 7.5∼12 and 2.5∼4 times higher than Pt-NP, respectively, indicating the better catalytic activity caused by larger surface area. The performance of Pt can be further modified via forming alloy, as the Pt3Sn alloy reported by Deshpande et al. using Sn as a promoter to alter the selectivity, resulting in hydroxylamine (NH3OH+) and ammonium mixed products [83]. The combination of thermodynamic and kinetic measurements in Fig. 7C shows that the addition of Sn and its conversion to hydroxylamine can improve the stability of HNO*. According to Fig. 7A, Ru also has the ability for electrocatalytic reduction of NO to ammonia. Casey-Stevens et al. [84] investigated the reaction mechanism and starting potential of the NO reduction to ammonia on the Ru surface via DFT calculations and found that the NO is normally adsorbed on the catalyst via N atoms, while the hydrogenation of NH to NH2 determines the reaction rate. In addition to theoretical calculations, the adsorption and reduction property of NO on Ru electrodes can be tested by real-time attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) combined with cyclic voltammetry [85]. Li et al. [33] reported a surface modification strategy to increase the performance of Ru nanosheets with high coordination number (Ru-HCN) by simple H2 plasma treatment, forming Ru nanosheets with low coordination number (Ru-LCN), as shown in Fig. 7D. The Ru-LCN exhibits significantly increased NH3 production of 45.02 μmol∙h − 1∙mg−1 and FE of 65.96% than Ru-HCN at a lower potential of −0.2 V versus RHE. The deformation of charge density implies that a decrease in coordination number favors the adsorption and activation of the N = O bond. The Gibbs free energies of NO adsorption on Ru-HCN and Ru-LCN (ΔG NO) are compared, which are −2.04 eV and −2.35 eV, respectively. By comparing the ∆G of various intermediates over the FCC (111) crystal plane of Ru-HCN and Ru-LCN, the optiaml NORR pathways are determined, showing the potential determining step (PDS) of *HNO → *HNOH, which has the ∆G of 0.62 eV for Ru-HCN and a lower ∆G of 0.27 eV for Ru-LCN, indicating the better NORR performance of Ru-LCN. 3.3.2 Non-noble metals and alloys Noble metals or their alloys can electrocatalytic reduce NO into ammonia, but due to their high cost and relatively low NH3 yield, researchers are constantly looking for new materials with high NORR activity. Cu-based electrocatalysts are appealing due to the unique electron configuration of Cu, which could be one of the most active NORR catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8 A, Long et al. [43] compared the ΔG of determining steps of NORR, HER, and NRR through DFT calculations, confirming the more feasible NORR over the Cu catalyst. The optimum activity of Cu can also be proved by the scaling relation of adsorption energies of NO on various metal surfaces. According to the calculation of the NORR kinetic barriers on the Cu surface, NH3 will be the main product of the electrocatalytic reduction of NO, because the barriers to the synthesis of N2, N2O, and NH3 from N* are 0.92 eV, 0.60 eV, and 0.50 eV, respectively. The NH3 yield reached 9234 μmol∙g − 1∙h − 1 with a FE of 93.5%, which is already at the level of ammonia production in the Haber-Bosch process. This study also indicates the effect of morphology, as copper foam with a large specific surface area shows better NH3 yield and FE than copper foil. The activity of Cu can be further modified with the doping of Ru to form Ru0.05Cu0.95, which reduces the d-band of Cu, and weakens the adsorption strength of NO, therefore, reducing the Gibbs free energy of the PDS reaction of *NO→*NHO, as well as the desorption energy of NH3, leading to increased NH3 yields of 17.68 μmol∙cm−2∙h − 1 and FE of 64.9% [59], as shown in Fig. 8B. In addition to Cu, Bi is also an efficient electrocatalyst for N2 fixation, CO2 hydrogenation, and O2 reduction. However, Choi et al. [47] discovered that Bi powder is not active for NRR, but it can efficiently electrocatalytic reduce NO to ammonia as well as convert NO2 −, NO3 −, and NO2 to ammonia at a specific potential, resulting in an NH3 yield of 6 ± 2 × 102 pmol∙s − 1∙cm−2 from NO. In Fig. 8C, Lin et al. [76] prepared Bi nano dendrites through electrodeposition, exposing sufficient active sites for NORR, achieving an NH3 yield of 1194 mg∙h − 1∙mg−1 and a FE of 89.2%. According to the density of states results, the redistribution of electrons between the Bi (012) surface and NO molecule lead to the elongation of the NO bond to 1.19 Å, indicating the activation of the NO molecule. The Gibbs free energies diagram implies a potential reaction pathway, with the potential determining step of *NO→*NOH. 3.4 Metal compounds for norr Although metals and alloys demonstrate good NORR performances due to their intrinsic activities and engineered surface active sites, the high price, low utilization rate of active metal atoms, and poor long-term stability, greatly impeded their practical applications. Therefore, owing to the earth-abundant reserves and unique electronic structures, various transition metal (TM) compounds, including metal oxides, phosphides, sulphides, carbides, and nitrides, as well as MOFs, have been proven effective in electro-reduction reactions, such as HER, NRR, CO2RR, and NORR. Table S2 compares the NORR activity characteristics of various metals compounds. 3.4.1 Transition-metal oxides The higher corrosion resistance of transition metal oxides (TMOs) make them suitable for NORR in acidic and oxidizing conditions. Sun's group has investigated the NORR activities of a series of metal oxides, including Fe2O3 nanorods [86], NiO nanosheet arrays [49], and MnO2 nanoarrays [87]. Fig. 9 A shows a NiO nanosheet array on titanium mesh (NiO/TM) [49], which has a lower ΔG (*NO) of −0.02 eV than 1.41 eV of ΔG (H), indicating the more stable adsorption of NO molecule than H to inhibit the competition of HER, achieving an NH3 yield of 2130 μg∙h − 1∙cm−2, FE of 90% at −0.6 V, and good stability. The optimal NORR pathway on NiO(200) is NONHONH2ONH2OHNH2 NH3. The density of states (DOS) of the forbidden band of NO adsorbed on NiO indicates good electrical conductivity of NiO/TM and facilitates the activation and reduction of *NO. While the Fe2O3 nanorods show an NH3 yield of 78.02 μmol∙h − 1∙cm−1 and FE of 86.73% in neutral media, and an NH3 yield of 145.28 μg∙h − 1∙mg−1 when the NORR is conducted in a Zn–NO battery [86]. In our previous report, we found TiO2 also exhibited excellent NORR activities, which can be further improved by anchoring ultrafine Cu nanoparticles [46], as shown in Fig. 9B. The large surface area and porous channels of Cu/P-TiO2 enhance the adsorption of NO, while the ultrafine Cu nanoparticles not only improve the electrical conductivity of TiO2 but also collect electrons from TiO2 and transfer them to NO molecules, therefore, facilitating the NORR performance and achieving an extremely high NH3 yield of 3520.80 μg⋅h − 1⋅mg−1 at −0.3 V with an FE of 86.49%. 3.4.2 Transition-metal phosphides and sulfides Transition-metal phosphides (TMPs) and sulfides (TMS) have attracted the attention of researchers due to unique structural features with more active sites, excellent electronic conductivity, and intrinsic electrocatalytic activity, which are being investigated for various applications. For example, the phosphides of Fe, Co, and Ni are the most widely investigated materials for HER. Recently, their electrocatalytic NO reduction performances are explored. Liang et al. fabricated FeP nanorods array on carbon cloth (FeP/CC) [52] and CoP nanoarray on Ti mesh (CoP/TM) [53], respectively, and investigated their NORR performances through DFT calculations and experiments. They found the activate of adsorbed NO on the FeP surface follows the donation-back donation mechanism, and *NH2→*NH3 is the potential determining step, leading to an NH3 yield of 85.62 μmol⋅h − 1⋅cm−2 and FE of 88.49% in 0.2 M phosphate buffer solution. While the CoP/TM shows an NH3 yield of 47.22 μmol⋅h − 1⋅cm−2 and FE of 88.3% at −0.2 V. The DOS result indicates the feasible adsorption of NO on Co atoms instead of P atoms, hence, Co atoms provide the active sites for NORR. Mou et al. [75] prepared Ni2P nanosheet arrays on carbon paper (Ni2P/CP) for NORR, which has an NH3 yield of 33.47 μmol⋅h − 1⋅cm−2 and a rather high FE of up to 76.9% at −0.2 V in 0.1 M hydrochloric acid, as well as excellent electrochemical durability under operating conditions. Ni2P is more likely to adsorb NO and inhibit HER because the surface adsorption energy of NO (−1.12 eV) is much lower than the −0.54 eV of H atoms. CoS and MoS2 are the most widely investigated transition-metal sulfides (TMS) in electrocatalytic and photocatalytic reactions. Zhang et al. confirmed the NORR activity of CoS, which has an NH3 yield of 27.02 μmol⋅cm−2⋅h − 1 and FE of 36.68% [88], as well as the MoS2 nanosheets (shown in Fig. 9C) with NH3 yield up to 99.6 μmol⋅cm−2⋅h − 1 and FE of 76.6% [77]. The exposed Mo-edge site of MoS2 has a positive charge of 1.74 e, which promotes NO adsorption and activation, and suppresses the binding of proton for HER and the coupling of the NN bond. In the NORR process, the electrons are transferred from MoS2 to adsorbed NO molecules (1.36 e), then the accumulated electrons on NO lead to the elongation of the N − O bond. The adsorption of NO on the MoS2 surface follows the donation-back donation mechanism. 3.4.3 Polyoxometalates clusters Polyoxometalate clusters (POMs) are serials of transition metal oxides clusters with metal-oxo units (usually V, Nb, Ta, Mo, and W) in which the metal ion acts as a polyhedral building block [89]. Owing to their unique characteristics of structure, geometry, and high redox activity, POMs have been applied in areas of electronic devices, energy storage, and particularly catalysis. Recently, Liang et al. [90] explored the mechanism and performances of a series of 3d–5d transition metal ions coordinated with SiW11 (TM-substituted polyoxotungstates) in the direct electrochemical reduction of NO to ammonia through DFT calculations, as illustrated in Fig. 10 A. The SiW11FeII was investigated as an example as it has the highest activity and selectivity. Through the interactions between dyz-ppπ* (β-HOMO) and dz2-ppπ* (β-HOMO−1), Fig. 8B depicts the bent binding of NO (142.3°) to the FeII center. The NO-bound complex would be better off in a quartet rather than a sextet state, according to the spin density plot in Fig. 10B, which also shows an antiferromagnetic spin-spin coupling between the NO fragment and FeII center. As the process of *NO + H+ + e− → *NHO is the rate-determining step, the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) and energy barrier (ΔG b) are calculated, as shown in Fig. 10C. The NO adsorption ability and the Gibbs energy change of the first hydrogenation process are not directly correlated. With barriers as low as 0.39 eV (PCM model), the initial NO bond activation on SiW11NiII is quite more advanced than SiW11FeII. The free energy diagram of SiW11NiII, SiW11FeII, and SiW11PdII illustrates that the NOER proceeds follow the same route of NO (g) → *NO → *NHO → *NHOH → *NH2OH → *NH2⋯H2O → *NH3 → NH4 + (l), as shown in Fig. 10D. 3.4.4 Novel 2D transition metal compounds Although various transition metal-based materials have been investigated, the NORR performances still require further improvement. Hence, the NORR performances of many kinds of novel transition metal-based materials are explored, among which the materials with 2D structures, such as transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) [91], 2D transition metal borides (MBenes) [92] and 2D metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [93], are attractive due to their unique and fascinating properties. Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) are typical 2D materials, which show unique electronic and mechanical properties with direct bandgap, therefore, attracting considerable attention in energy harvesting, flexible electronics, optoelectronics, and electrocatalysis [91]. As shown in Fig. 11 A, Tursun et al. [94] systematically investigated the NOER performances of a series of 1T’ phase single-layer TMDs (including MoS2, MoSe2, MoTe2, WTe2, and TaTe2) through DFT calculations. The reaction pathway is determined by the coverage of NO. At low NO coverage, the O atom of *NO is protonated to form *NOH, and produce ammonia through the reaction pathway of *NO→*NOH→*N→*NH→*NH2→*NH3. While at high NO coverage, *NO dimers will be formed, leading to the yield of N2O or N2. As HER is the primary competing reaction of NORR, they further compared the limiting potentials of NOER (UL(NOER)) and HER (UL(HER)) over the five TMD catalysts, indicating the higher selectivity of NOER than the suppressed HER. Two-dimensional metal borides (MBenes) are a novel class of two-dimensional material that has received extensive theoretical and experimental attention. He et al. [95] used DFT calculations to investigate the feasibility of MBenes (CrB, MnB, MoB, HfB, and WB) for NORR and discovered that all MBenes exhibited good catalytic properties, particularly MnB. Fig. 11B illustrates the NORR performances of a range of MBenes investigated by Xiao et al. [92] through DFT calculations. Most of the MBenes show more negative ΔG *NO than ΔG *NH3 and ΔG*H values according to the adsorption energies of NO, NH3, and H on MBenes, suggesting the more favorable NORR than HER and ammoxidation. While the ΔG *NH3 of Mn2B2, Fe2B2, and Rh2B2 are more negative than their ΔG *N2 and ΔG *N2O, indicating the high selectivity in converting NO to NH3. Zhang et al. reported iron diboride (FeB2) [96] and vanadium diboride (VB2) [97] for NORR through experimental and DFT investigations, and found B sites are the key active centers for NORR, which facilitate the protonation and inhibit the HER, therefore, boosting the activity and selectivity. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous materials with a large specific surface area and adjustable porous structure. While 2D MOFs show shortened diffusion distance and high surface-to-volume atom ratios due to the unique ultra-thin monolayer. Huang et al. [93] investigated the NORR performances of a serial of 2D MOFs with hexaaminobenzene (HAB) ligands as illustrated in Fig. 11C. Adsorption Gibbs free energies are used to compare the sorption of NO and H on various TM-HAB monolayers. The binding of NO molecules on TM-HAB monolayers is stronger than H, which may suppress H adsorption competition. Co- and Rh-HAB MOFs are considered suitable for the electrochemical NO reduction, which would go through the following two possible reaction pathways: At low NO coverage, NO can be reduced to NH3 through both *NOH and *HNO pathways, involving five net coupled proton and electron transfer. While at high NO coverage, NO dimer will be formed through 2NO (g) + 2H+ + 2e = N2O + H2O (l). 3.5 Metal-free materials for norr Although metal-based NORR catalysts are effective, they still suffer from the limitations of metal ion release, unstable in acidic conditions, and limited reserves. Earth-abundant metal-free electrocatalysts can avoid these issues. Carbon nanomaterials, including carbon nanofibers, carbon nanotubes [98], carbon nitride [99], graphene, graphyne [100], boron phosphide [101], and their modified composites, are regarded most attractive metal-free NORR catalysts due to their excellent conductivity and chemical stability. Zhang et al. [101] explored the NORR performance of a metal-free boron phosphide (BP) for the first time, obtaining a high NH3 yield rate of 96.6 μmol⋅h − 1⋅cm−2 and FE of 83.3%. In the BP, the B and P atoms serve as dual-active centers for NORR process, therefore, synergistically activate NO for boosted NH3 generation. As shown in Fig. 12 A, Ouyang et al. [102] reported a highly selective, active, and stable honeycomb of carbon nanofibres with a porous structure that can effectively trap NO gas and enhance the interaction between catalyst and NO molecules in addition to increasing the surface area of the catalyst and expose more active sites, therefore, achieving an NH3 yield of 22.35 μmol⋅h − 1⋅cm−2 and FE of 88.33%. The Gibbs free energies of three types of catalysts with -COOH, -O, and -OH functional groups are calculated to determine the potential determining step (PDS) and reaction pathway. The reduction of NO is determined by the attraction between the hydrogen atoms in the -OH group and the oxygen atoms in the NO molecule through *NO + H → *HNO. The catalyst with the -OH group appears most favorable for NORR because its energy barrier for PDS is only 0.29 eV, which is lower than 0.57 eV of -COOH, 0.33 eV of -O, and 0.31 eV for HER. As a novel metal-free 2D material, graphene has been widely applied in desalination, medicine, electronics, energy storage, and catalysis. Graphene-based catalysts have been proven suitable for NH3 production via NRR [104]. Recently, their applications in NORR are getting attractive and are being investigated more and more. Both N-doped graphene and boron-doped graphene are efficient metal-free electrocatalysts for NORR, benefiting from the better NO adsorption-desorption facilitated by the pyridinic-N or boron atoms [85,86]. Graphene is also an ideal substrate for constructing heterostructured materials to enhance their catalytic activities. Saeidi et al. [105] investigated the NORR mechanism of Si atoms coordinated N4 centers decorated graphene (Si-N4Gr) through DFT calculations. NO can be highly activated and then reduced into NH3 at low NO coverage over the Si-N4Gr electrocatalyst. Similar results were obtained by Wang et al. [106] in the conversion of NO to NH3 on a single metal atom anchored pyrrole-type defective graphene. Nitrides, including monolayer carbon nitride (C2N), boron-embedded C3N nanosheets [107], and hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) [108], have recently been applied as promising electrocatalysts or substrates for NORR. Zang et al. [109] investigated the NORR performance of a diatom catalyst (BAC) of Cr2 C2N and found that the NORR products could be tuned by the NO coverage on Cr2 C2N to produce NH3 or N2O. Wu et al. [103] designed a non-metal P-doped monolayer C2N (P@C2N) by DFT calculations and found only 2P@C2N exhibited high NORR selectivity, excellent catalytic activity, and fast reaction rates. As shown in Fig. 12B, NO is stably adsorbed on the catalyst surface through the side-on state (Ead = −0.48 eV). The π* orbital of NO interacts with the sp3 orbital of P to form an occupied sp3-π* orbital and an unoccupied sp3-π* orbital, according to the projected density of states (PDOS). The pCOHPs plot of the N = O bond of adsorbed NO indicates that the N = O bond is weakened and NO is activated. The optimal NORR pathway on 2P@C2N is derived by comparing the free energy of each basic reaction, in which N2O, N2, and H2 are the potential by-products. The rate-limiting step is *NH→*NH2 with a maximum kinetic barrier of 0.45 eV. The turnover frequency (TOF) is 8.9 × 105 per s per site for the synthesis of NH3 on 2P@C2N at 400 K, which is two orders of magnitude greater than the TOF for Pt (3.0 × 103 per s per sit), indicating an ultra-fast reaction rate. Hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) is a graphene-insulating isostructure that can be converted from graphene, but electron transfer is hampered by the insulated h-BN, resulting in a relatively large reflective energy barrier during NORR. To overcome this restriction, Zhou et al. [110] modified the hBN-graphene heterostructure with a Ccenter-CN2 structure by inserting boron and nitrogen atoms into the graphene side of the hBN-graphene interface, in which Ccenter-CN2 acts as an electron donor to facilitate NO activation and as a transporter for electron transfer between the intermediate and hBN-graphene, while hBN-graphene serves as an electron reservoir to facilitate carrier movement, achieving a fairly low limiting potential of −0.22 V. Moreover, the hBN-graphene heterostructures can efficiently suppress the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction of NORR. 3.6 The novel techniques for improving activity of electrocatalysts 3.6.1 Defect engineering Defect engineering is one of the versatile surface modification techniques for tuning the catalytic activity of various materials, which has been widely applied in energy storage, sensing, photocatalysis, and electrocatalysis. Introducing vacancies is a typical defect engineering method to improve the intrinsic properties of metal oxides and metal sulfides. He et al. [111] incorporated oxygen vacancy in CeO2 (111) nanosheet surfaces to improve the interconversion between Ce3+ and Ce4+ through the storage and release of the 4f electronic orbit, hence, the OV site is the most active reduction surface for NORR. Li et al. [112] also employed a defect engineering strategy to introduce S-vacancy defects into SnS2− x , which delivers an exceptional NORR performance of an NH3 yield of 78.6 μmol⋅h − 1⋅cm−2 and FE of 90.3%. Zhang et al. [88] also reported CoS nanosheets with sulfur vacancies (CoS1-x) as an effective NORR catalyst, achieving a high NH3 yield of 44.67 μmol⋅cm−2⋅h − 1 and FE of 53.62%, which is superior to pure CoS with NH3 yield of 27.02 μmol⋅cm−2⋅h − 1 and FE of 36.68%, as illustrated in Fig. 13 A. Sulfur vacancies enhance the conductivity of the catalyst and expand the electrochemical surface to expose additional active sites. The required energy for adsorbing NO is reduced from 1.71 eV to 1.07 eV as a result of the sulfur vacancies. Due to the localization of electrons around the sulfur vacancies, the decreased adsorption strength of NO on CoS1-x results in a lower energy barrier for the potential determining step (PDS) of NO activation (*NO + H → *NOH), which considerably increases the activation of NO molecules. 3.6.2 Crystal structure engineering The crystal structure is an important parameter for metal catalysts, in which the facet exhibits significant influence on the activity and selectivity. Therefore, people can modulate the catalytic activity in the reduction of NO, nitrite [113], and nitrate [114] by controlling the exposure of specific crystal facets. Rosca et al. [115] examined the performance of catalytic reduction of absorbed NO on the surface of Pt (100), Pt (110), and Pt (111) into ammonia, and found Pt (100) breaks the N = O bond more easily. Chun et al. [116] reported the probable pathways of NO electro-reduction reaction on Pt{100} using DFT and kMC simulations. Patil et al. [114] fabricated copper nano dendrites (Cu NDs) dominant with the {200} facet, as shown in Fig. 13B, and applied it in the NORR, showing FE of 95.5%, which is higher than the 80% of the {111} facet dominant Cu. Although Patil et al. only investigated the electrocatalytic reduction of nitrite, the DFT calculation results reveal much lower activation energy for NO dissociation on Cu{200} and Cu{220} than Cu{111}, hence, indicating the great potential of Cu{200} and Cu{220} in NO reduction. 3.6.3 Dispersion of catalytic component on substrate It is known that only the surface active sites are active in the NORR, therefore, minimizing particle size to expose more active sites is an effective way to enhance the catalytic activity. However, the aggregation of nano-size particles greatly inhibits the performance of catalysts. The decoration of nanoparticles on the substrate can effectively achieve good dispersion of catalytic components. Liu et al. [118] decorated Bi nanoparticles on carbon nanosheets (Bi@C), which demonstrated a maximum FE of 93% at −0.4 V, a maximum NH3 yield of 1592.5 μg⋅h − 1⋅mg−1 at −0.7 V, and good NORR stability. Liu et al. [74] fabricated a CoSe2@CNTs hybrid, which combines the outstanding NO adsorption ability of CoSe2 and the good conductivity of carbon nanotubes, and investigated its performance in electrocatalytic selective reduction of NO. The formation of the NH bond is occurred on the specific spatial structure of CoSe2, while the formation of the NN bond is inhibited, therefore, resulting in high selectivity and ammonia yield in the NORR process. Muthusamy et al. [117] fabricated a binder-free NiNC@CF electrode through a two-step process by growing carbon nitride nanostructures (NiNC) wrapped by MOF-derived zero-valent nickel nanoparticles on carbon fiber (CF), as shown in Fig. 13C. The Ni nanoparticles with uniform coating are well dispersed on the CF surface, which provide the primary NORR active sites, and hampered the corrosion of nickel nanoparticles by the porous N-doped carbon microstructure, achieving an NH3 yield of 94 μmol⋅h − 1⋅cm−2 and FE of 87%. 3.6.4 Metal single-atom catalysts for norr The pure noble metal catalysts suffer restrictions of low utilization and high cost, therefore, hamper the industrial scale applications. In recent years, emerging single-atom catalysts (SACs) provide an effective way to solve the above problems by decorating isolated metal atoms on the substrate to obtain excellent catalytic activity. As a cutting-edge field in catalysis, the NORR performances of SACs have also been widely investigated, indicating the high activity, stability, and selectivity of SACs [80]. Wu et al. systematically investigated the electrocatalytic NO reduction performance of g-C3N4 decorated with a series of transition metal single-atom through first-principles computations [50]. The Cu single-atom modified g-C3N4 (Cu@g-C3N4) exhibits the best NORR performance at low NO coverage with a low limiting potential of 0.371 V and extremely high stability. In the NORR process, the Cu single atom attracts the majority of the electrons on Cu@g-C3N4, leading to the accumulation of electrons at the Cu single atom, on which the NO molecule is activated to form NH3. The competing hydrogen evolution reaction can be efficiently suppressed by the Cu@g-C3N4, leading to a high FE. In addition to g-C3N4, there is still a variety of metal-free materials that have been used as the substrate for decorating metal single-atom. Wang et al. [119] used graphene as a substrate and embedded Co–N4 moiety to get a Co-N4/graphene single-atom-catalyst for NORR. According to the first-principles molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, NO molecules are moderately activated to form HNO* from the first protonation of NO, producing NH3 at low NO coverage or N2O at higher NO coverage. Similarly, Si-N4 embedded graphene [105] and TM-N4 anchored pyrrole-type graphene [106] also exhibited excellent NORR activity. Phthalocyanine (Pc) is also an ideal substrate that provides abundant binding sites for the immobilization of transition metal single-atom to avoid agglomeration. Liu et al. [120] studied the NORR performances of 2D TM-Pc sheets by DFT simulations. The 2D Co-Pc sheet is found the best NORR catalyst due to the proper NO absorption energy and relatively low limiting potential. At low NO coverage, the adsorbed NO will be hydrogenated by reacting with electron-coupled protons to form ammonia through NORR, instead of generating H2 through competing for HER reaction, as the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) for the adsorption of H is positive. Wu et al. [42] applied nitrogen-doped BP monolayer as the substrate for the decoration of 29 transition-metal single-atoms for NORR, demonstrating that MoN3/BP and IrN3/BP SACs are promising electrocatalysts with limiting potentials of −0.10 V and −0.06 V, respectively. By comparing the charge numbers of Mo or Ir atoms, N3/BP, and various intermediates, it was determined that N3/BP acts as an electron reservoir to facilitate carrier mobility, the Mo or Ir atom acts as an electron donor to facilitate NO activation and as a transmitter for rapid charge transfer between the intermediates and N3/BP. 4 Mechanistic insight into norr NO molecule is unstable and chemically active due to the unpaired electrons in its orbitals (1σ22σ23σ24σ21π45σ22π1), which has lower bond dissociation energy than nonpolar N2, therefore, can be reduced into NH3 more readily [75]. The π-antibonding state (ppπ*) generated by the p orbitals of the N and O atoms is primarily responsible for the adsorption behavior of NO in the reaction [90]. By conducting theoretical calculations with the help of the volcano diagram model, as illustrated in Fig. 14 A, Wan and Long et al. studied the viability of NORR on various metal surfaces [43,81]. Prior to recently, the majority of research on the electrochemical conversion of NO was centered on the generation of N2, although ammonia production has recently piqued interest. Various reaction conditions, such as different catalysts, NO concentrations, electrolytes, and pH, were studied when examining the NORR performances. Numerous products, including NH3, N2, N2O, NH2OH, and H2, are produced during the NORR process depending on the potential, which is given by the following equations [51,81,121]: (3) NO + 5 (H + + e− ) → NH3 + H2O E0=0.71 V vs. RHE (4) 2 NO + 4 (H + + e− ) → N2 + 2H2O E0=1.68 V vs. RHE (5) 2 NO + 2 (H + + e− ) → N2O + H2O E0=1.59 V vs. RHE (6) NO + 3(H + + e− ) → NH2OH E0=0.38 V vs. RHE (7) 2(H + + e− ) → H2 E0=0 V vs. RHE The NORR is severely hampered by the HER of Eq. (5), which occurs at a potential below 0 V vs. RHE in an aqueous solution. As a result, the suppression of HER is extensively investigated through the development of NORR catalysts as well as the optimization of electrochemical experimental systems. Although some theoretical and experimental calculations on NORR have been studied, the understanding of the reaction pathway and the catalytic activation of NO is still limited. The first stage in the NORR process is the adsorption of NO molecules on catalyst surfaces, which dictates the subsequent reaction pathway. Both lateral and terminal NO adsorption arrangements are illustrated in Fig. 14B. According to the Sabatier principle, the adsorption strength of reactants should be moderate, because the adsorption and activation of NO cannot be accomplished at weaker adsorption strength, while stronger adsorption strength will prevent the desorption of products [42,50,122]. Fig. 14C shows the computation of intermediate isomer adsorption and dissociation to establish the potential reaction pathways [123]. Currently, the most frequently accepted NO activation mechanism is the donation-backdonation mechanism [42,63,75,103,110]. As shown in Fig. 14D, the vacant d orbitals hold the lone-pair electrons from the occupied orbitals of the NO molecule, and the occupied d orbitals counter-donate electrons to the anti-bonding orbital (π*) of the NO molecule, resulting in the elongation of N = O to produce activated NO molecule. As shown in Fig. 14E, the dissociative and associative pathways are potential NORR reaction pathways according to theoretical investigations [43]. The adsorbed NO molecules on the catalyst surface undergo a dissociative route in which the N = O bond breaks into activated nitrogen (N*) and oxygen (O*) atoms, which are then hydrogenated to produce NH3 and H2O, respectively. However, a significant amount of energy must be consumed to break the N = O bond. Calculation results show that the NO* → N* + O* activation barriers on Pt (111), Pt (100), and MoS2 surfaces are 2.32 eV, 0.99 eV, and 2.41 eV, respectively, which are challenging to overcome at ambient temperature [45,116,124]. The NO molecules in the associative pathway are continuously reduced to NH3 and H2O after being hydrogenated first to form the intermediate HxNOHy. Compared to the dissociative pathway, this reaction requires substantially less energy to break the NO bond in HxNOHy. The distal-O, distal-N, alternating-O, and alternating-N pathways are additional divisions of the associative pathway. The distal-O (or -N) pathway allows the complete hydrogenation of the -O (or -N) atom in NO to H2O (or NH3) before further atomic reduction. The -O and -N should be alternately hydrogenated in the alternating-O (or -N) route. In general, the investigation of NORR is still in its early stage, hence, the reduction mechanism of the NORR process is still being developed, and neither experimental nor theoretical investigations are sufficient. Many methods, including density functional theory simulation, differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS), and electrochemical in-situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, have been applied to investigate the NORR reaction pathways. Furthermore, the experimental and theoretical calculations can provide theoretical guidance in the adjustment of physical and chemical features of NORR catalysts to obtain improved electrocatalytic performance in future studies. 5 Summary and outlook The electrocatalytic reduction of NO under ambient conditions is an ideal strategy for reducing air pollution and the massive energy consumption in NH3 synthesis, and it has a high potential to replace the resource and energy-intensive SCR and Haber-Bosch processes. Although the reports on NORR have increased in recent years, the reported materials for NORR have not yet reached the energy efficiency and NH3 yield of the Haber-Bosch process, and continue to face significant challenges in many areas. The status of current NORR studies and perspectives are illustrated as follows: (i) Theoretical prediction is a powerful tool that, in the majority of NORR reports, can direct studies to avoid repeating experiments, increase research productivity, and simulate a variety of extreme conditions, including high temperatures, single atoms, and specific atom doping at specific locations. Additionally, the DFT calculation is used to investigate the NORR mechanisms, including NO adsorption and activation processes, theoretical reaction pathways, intermediate products, etc. However, the kinetics, including reactant activation energy and reaction rate, should also be taken into account when examining the NORR mechanism because doing so could lead to inconsistent results if the transition state is ignored and only the Gibbs free energies of the reactants and products are taken into account. Advanced in-situ methods, such as online differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) and in-situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, can also be used in conjunction with DFT calculations to reveal the reaction pathways of NORR. (ii) The effective NORR catalysts with high NH3 yields and FE should be further developed. The vast majority of NORR catalysts are metal-based, while more non-metallic catalysts like C, B, P, and N are attracting interest. The metal-based catalysts, especially precious-metal catalysts, face the problem of high cost and the low utilization rate of metal atoms. Researchers adjusted the morphology of metals into nanoparticles, nanosheets, nano dendrites, nanoalloys, and emerging single atoms to increase the surface area and expose more active sites to improve NORR catalysts. Additionally, decorating metals on a variety of substrates, including semiconductors, non-metallic materials, conductive 2D materials, etc., can also enhance the dispersion of metals and achieve good NORR activity. Surface modification techniques, such as surface defects and elemental doping, are also important for improving the performance of non-metallic catalysts. In summary, the electrocatalytic reduction of NO to produce NH3 has piqued interest and has been steadily progressing. Although there are still many obstacles to overcome, theoretical calculations, experimental optimization, and the development of new characterization techniques are helpful to improve NORR accuracy while also improving NORR catalysts. The breakthrough in NORR may bring us a cleaner environment, a clean energy carrier, and a green ammonia synthesis industry, in our opinion. coredata.dc:description: Fossil fuel combustion results in significant NOx emissions, which are harmful to the environment and human health. The reasonable and effective treatment of NOx pollution is an urgent requirement. The electrocatalytic reduction of nitric oxide (NORR) to ammonia is an emerging method that can convert the NO pollutant into an important industrial product under ambient conditions, exhibiting great advantages over the severe reaction conditions of selective catalytic reduction (SCR) and Haber-Bosch processes of NH3 synthesis, therefore, attracting the great interest of researchers. In the last few years, lots of materials for NORR have been developed based on theoretical, computational, or experimental studies. However, further breakthroughs in the catalytic activity, selectivity, and Faraday efficiency of NORR electrocatalysts are required to address the limitations in practical applications. To help future research on NORR in both theoretical and experimental directions, we summarized the recent progress in the development of NORR electrocatalysts, classifying them into metals and alloys, metal compounds, and non-metal materials according to their nature. The mechanisms or reaction pathways of NORR are also discussed. Furthermore, the experimental parameters and devices for NORR are introduced to help with experimental studies in the future. The research directions and perspectives on the further development of NORR electrocatalysts are illustrated.
coredata.dc:title: Recent progress in electrocatalytic reduction of nitric oxide to ammonia
